abstract.p: Sun Microsystems plans to introduce two computers that are first of new generation of systems intended to raise performance of high end of Sun's product line; computers--desktop work station and workgroup servicer--are priced to start at $10,000 (S)

block.p: Sun Microsystems plans to introduce on Wednesday two computers that are the first of a new generation of systems intended to raise the performance of the high end of Sun's product line.

The two computers -- a desktop work station and a workgroup server -- will be based on a long-delayed microprocessor, the Ultrasparc III, that Sun said would double the speed of software applications.
Sun Microsystems plans to introduce on Wednesday two computers that are the first of a new generation of systems intended to raise the performance of the high end of Sun's product line.

The two computers -- a desktop work station and a workgroup server -- will be based on a long-delayed microprocessor, the Ultrasparc III, that Sun said would double the speed of software applications.
Prices of the two computers will start at $10,000.
The systems, part of the company's new Net Effect strategy, will operate at speeds of 750 and 900 megahertz and will scale up to 1.5 gigahertz, the company said.
Sun also plans to introduce software that can tie together computers on a network to increase performance.

The new machines are 64-bit systems, a design that permits computers to manage vast databases of information easily. Intel is working on its own 64-bit design, known as Itanium, but it will not become available commercially until the first half of next year.
